title: Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus Orders the Beheading of his Son
titles: Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus Beheading his Son
description: Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus laat zijn zoon onthoofden. De consul zit op een troon tussen twee zuilen. Op de grond het lichaam van de zoon; de beul houdt het afgehakte hoofd omhoog. Rechts een soldaat met een paard. Op de achtergrond gebouwen van Rome.

iconClassDescription: Torquatus has his son beheaded because he has fought an enemy in single combat against the strict orders of his father

documentation: F. Grijzenhout, 'Tempel voor Nederland : De Nationale Konst-Gallerij in 's-Gravenhage', Nederlands Kunsthistorische Jaarboek 35 (1984), p. 29, afb. 25.
longTitle: Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus Orders the Beheading of his Son, Ferdinand Bol, 1661 - 1663
subTitle: h 218cm × w 242cm
scLabelLine: Ferdinand Bol (1616–1680), oil on canvas, c. 1661–1664

label.title: Consul Titus Manlius Torquatus Orders the Beheading of his Son
label.makerLine: Ferdinand Bol (1616–1680), oil on canvas, c. 1661–1664
label.description:
This picture was painted for the headquarters of the Admiralty of Amsterdam. It represents a story from Roman times in which a consul condemns his son to be beheaded for ignoring a command. The Admiralty
intended this image to proclaim that insubordination would be severely punished. It also reminded officers
that they must always remain impartial.
